LEADIN:
The under sea eruption of a volcano near Tonga last month disturbed an outer layer of the Earth's atmosphere according to NASA.
But thanks to this finding, scientists hope to develop a much faster warning system for eruptions which could save lives.
STORYLINE:
When Tonga's Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai volcano erupted last month, it destroyed buildings, covered the island nation in ash and sent tsunami waves thousands of miles away.

The 15 January eruption also produced acoustic shockwaves that disturbed the ionosphere, the outer layer of the Earth's atmosphere that contains electrons ionised by the sun, according to NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory based in Pasadena, California.
The disturbance was detected by the lab's Global Differential Global Positioning System (GDGPS), that monitors the density of electrons in the ionosphere.

"We started to pull the data and started to see if it created a signature in the ionosphere. And sure enough, we found lots of different kinds of signals that this eruption produced," says Siddharth Krishnamoorthy, research technologist at NASA.
Data from the volcanic eruption will help NASA in its efforts to develop an early-warning system for tsunamis by tracking changes in the ionosphere, Krishnamoorthy says.
Most countries currently monitor for tsunamis by using buoys to track wave activity off their coasts, but these systems don't give communities much warning before a tsunami strikes.

A tsunami warning system based on ionosphere disturbances could give communities much earlier notice to help protect lives and property, but it will take many more years and much more data to make it reliable, according to Krishnamoorthy.
"If we can detect a tsunami in the open ocean in real time, that gives you several more hours to evacuate coasts, coastlines," he says.
